Interesting question! My knee-jerk response is oxygen, of course! We consume oxygen with every breath! If we stop consuming oxygen, we’ve got about 90 seconds of consciousness and about 3 minutes left to live, give or take. But hear me out: is oxygen the most abundant element in terms of sheer number of atoms consumed? And that’s hard to say! I’m going to make some assumptions and see where they lead. The chemical make-up of your body is more-or-less constant, at least among the top five elements or so. You’re not likely to see a shake-up in the top slots (and still be alive to tell about it, anyway).The chemical make-up of the consumables you put in your body (air, water, food) is probably about the same as the chemical make-up of your body. If you were ingesting one element at a far greater rate than any others, that element would have a greater representation in your body chemistry than any other elements.So it stands to reason that the most abundant elements in your body are also probably also the elements you consume most frequently. And as it turns out, we know which elements those are.By mass, the most abundant element in the average human body is indeed oxygen. That’s not terribly surprising: not only do we inhale oxygen from the air, but it’s part of the water we drink, and also a large part of the food we eat. But by atom, the most abundant element in our bodies is hydrogen. Take a look at this chart:  SOURCE: Chemical Elements of the Human Body Suppose your body has a mass of 70 kilograms (about 154 pounds). 65.0% of your body mass is oxygen, or about 45.5 kilograms of oxygen. Doing a few quick conversions: [math]45.5 \text{ kg oxygen} \times \left(\dfrac{1000 \text{ g}}{1 \text{ kg}}\right) \times \left(\dfrac{1 \text{ mol oxygen}}{16.00 \text{ g oxygen}}\right) = 2840\text{ mol oxygen}[/math] 18.5% of your body mass is carbon, or about 13.0 kilograms of carbon in a 70 kilogram body. [math]13.0 \text{ kg carbon} \times \left(\dfrac{1000 \text{ g}}{1 \text{ kg}}\right) \times \left(\dfrac{1 \text{ mol carbon}}{12.01 \text{ g carbon}}\right) = 1080\text{ mol carbon}[/math] 9.5% of your body is hydrogen, or about 6.7 kilograms of hydrogen in a 70 kilogram body. [math]6.7 \text{ kg hydrogen} \times \left(\dfrac{1000 \text{ g}}{1 \text{ kg}}\right) \times \left(\dfrac{1 \text{ mol hydrogen}}{1.01 \text{ g hydrogen}}\right) = 6600\text{ mol hydrogen}[/math] 3.2% of your body is nitrogen, or about 2.2 kilograms of nitrogen in a 70 kilogram body. [math]2.2 \text{ kg nitrogen} \times \left(\dfrac{1000 \text{ g}}{1 \text{ kg}}\right) \times \left(\dfrac{1 \text{ mol nitrogen}}{14.01 \text{ g nitrogen}}\right) = 160\text{ mol nitrogen}[/math] So there you have it. By mass, oxygen is by far the most abundant element in our body (and therefore, one assumes, the element we absorb the most of by mass). But in terms of sheer number of atoms, hydrogen has a hefty lead over any other element. Because of its small atomic weight, it doesn’t dominate in the mass category, but it’s present in so many organic molecules (as well as in water), and in such high ratios, that it only makes sense we would consume a huge number of hydrogen atoms in our daily activities.
